CHRIST

THE PUPIL OF BUDDHA

A COMPARATIVE STUDY.

/

NEW YORK,

Christ, The Pupil of Buddha.

PREFACE.

In this pamphlet a brief view is presented of the Eastern philosophy, the result of years of study and research of some of the most learned scholars and thinkers of the present age.

It is hoped that its brevity may recommend it to many who, although in a general way conversant with the facts here pre¬ sented, would not take the time or feel the inclination to examine more voluminous works, such for instance as Lillie’s Buddhism in Christendom.

It is from that exhaustive and far reaching book that the idea and in fact most of the material of the present booklet have been derived. If the reader will but divest himself of the pre¬ judice lurking in all of us, and impartially examine the following brief compilation, he cannot but marvel at the wondeiTul resem¬ blance that Christianity bears to Buddhism, nor fail to under¬ stand the reason thereof.

CHAPTER I.

That Jesus was the issue of a spirit father and a mortal mother is taught us from lisping childhood to tottering age, and, this doctrine being the foundation of Christianity, to doubt it would be, in the eyes of the faithful, an act meet for damnation.

Yet, to a Christian stud 3 r ing the Hindu religion, the most striking and surprising feature will be the oft recurring description of a “divine spirit” in human form. Considering that the world to-day possesses authentic documents in the Sanskrit language, which prove beyond a doubt the existence of Rrahminism and Buddhism some thousands of years before the birth of Jesus, it is rather more than remarkable that scattered through their holy books are found descriptions and narratives so similar to the story of Jesus, that faith gives way to doubt and doubt is lost in amazement.

For instance, one of the most prominent personages of miraculous birth mentioned in the scriptures of India, is “Chrisna.” Sir Wm. Jones, one of the first linguists and Oriental scholars that England has produced, speaks of him as follows in one of his lectures : “On page 375 of the principal Sanskrit dictionary, compiled about two thousand years ago, Chrisna is called the divine spirit in human form.”

After expatiating on this theme, he continues: “One singular fact must not be suffered to pass unnoticed—that the name (which is similar to Christ) and the general outline of his story were long anterior to the birth of our Saviour, and probably to the time of Homer, we know very certainly.”

Sir Wm. Jones further says, that Chrisna is described as the meekest and best-tempered of beings, washing the feet of the Brahmas, performing miracles, healing the sick, and comforting the poor, etc., etc.

6

After Chrisna’s, another miraculous birth occurred, namely, that of “ Gautama-Buddha.” His birth is recorded as having taken place some six hundred years before that of Jesus, and in the southern scriptures of India, as well as in the northern ones, the conception of “Gautama-Buddha” is described as immaculate. In the “ Lalita Vistara” (one of the holy books), translated from the Sanskrit by Seydel, the conception of Buddha is told as follows : “ Thus, O monks, Buddha was born, and the right side of his mother was not pierced, was not wounded ; it remained as before.”

Another instance of similarity between the two religions, and one equally remarkable, is that Buddhism, like Christianity, is founded on a trinity. When we consider that the idea of Father, Son and Holy Ghost is generally believed to be a strictly Christian dispensation, the fact that Buddhism possesses the very same theory regarding the deity becomes a startling revelation. “There is no possibility for error, for Buddhism, of all creeds, has the most trustworthy archives.” (.Arthur Lillie.)

In order to show more plainly the similarities of the two religions in regard to the Trinity, extracts from each are repro¬ duced here in parallel columns. The Buddhistic version is taken from Arthur Lillie’s book on Buddhism in Christendom, and authorities are given :

BUDDHIST TRINITY.

The Buddhist Trinity con¬ sists of :

1st. Buddha. He is the creator of all the Buddhas. He is the creator of Prajna and of the world, himself un¬ made.

2nd. Dharma or Prajna.

3rd. Sangha.

From the Nama Sangiti, by Mr. Hodgson.

CHRISTIAN TRINITY. There is one person of the Father, another of ' the Son, and another of the Holy Ghost.

The Athanasian Creed.

BUDDHISM. CHRISTIANITY.

Sangha, the third person of “God made the world by this Trinity, sprang from the means of the word and union of Sophia the mother, Sophia.”

and Buddha (spirit). Irenaeus, a Christian Bishop of the Second

From the Nama Sangiti, by Mr. Hodgson. Century.

Although Judaism was perhaps the only ancient religion which was strictly monotheistic, it is nevertheless very strange that the Buddhistic idea of the Deity should be trinitarian, exactly as is the Christian.

But in addition to this idea of a Trinity, as M. Ernest de Bunsen says : (Angel Messiah, page 50)

“The most ancient of the Buddhistic records known to us contain statements about the life and the doctrines of Gautama- Buddha, which correspond in a remarkable manner and impos¬ sibly by mere chance, with the traditions recorded in the Gospels about the life and doctrines of Jesus Christ.”

Now let us try by a few parallel paragraphs to learn how wonderfully similar to the story of Buddha is that of the life of Jesus as told in the Gospels. In the first place, let us compare these two paragraphs relating to the mysterious conception of both Buddha and Jesus.

MIRACULOUS CONCEPTION OF BUDDHA.

It is recorded that when Queen Maya received the Su¬ pernal Buddha in her womb, she said to her husband, 4 4 Listen; I saw the three regions (earth, heaven and hell) with a great light shining in the darkness, and myriads of spirits sang my praises in the sky.”

Lalita Vistara, by Fourcaux, page 63.

MIRACULOUS CONCEPTION OF JESUS.

And the angel came in unto her (Mary), and said : Hail, thou that art highly favored, the Lord is with thee, blessed art thou among women :

And behold, thou shalt con¬ ceive in thy womb and bring forth a son, and shalt call his name Jesus.

St. Luke, chapter I, verses 28th and 31st.

8

The spirits of the Pure Abode, flying ' in the air, showed half of their forms, and hymned King ' Suddhodana thus: f ‘Guer¬ doned with righteousness and gentle pity, adored on earth and in the shining sky, the com¬ ing Buddha quits the glorious spheres, and hies to earth to gentle Maya’s womb.”

Lalita Vistara, by Fourcaux, page 62.

But while he thought on these things, behold, the angel of the Lord appeared unto him (Joseph) in a dream, saying, Joseph, thou son of David, fear not to take unto thee Mary thy wife : for that which is conceived in her is of the Holy Ghost.”

St. Matthew,-chapter I., verse 20.

Observe how the birth of a child begotten by a holy spirit was proclaimed by angels to Queen Maya and, again, to her husband, even as the Gospel tells us was the case with Mary and Joseph before the birth of Jesus. Another resemblance between the

stories of Buddha and Jesus is found in their descent. While

Buddha is described as the son of a King, the Gospel is also very particular to tell us that Jesus descended by direct lineage from King David. The stories also agree in the circumstances of the births, both Queen Maya and Mary being on a journey, as the following paragraphs will show:

BIRTH OF BUDDHA.

Queen Maya when ten months gone with child was seized with a desire to return to her father’s city. And on the way the pains of labour seized her, and the Sala tree bent down its branches to over-shadow her. Then the infant Buddha came forth, and the great Kings of the four cardinal points re¬ ceived him in a cloth net. Two miraculous jets of water came from the sky to baptize him.

Lillie, chapter II. page 18.

BIRTH OF JESUS.

And Joseph also went up from Galilee, out of the city of Nazareth into Judea, unto the city of David which is called Bethlehem ; because he was of the house and lineage of David: And so it was, that while they were there, the days were ac¬ complished that she should be delivered.

And she brought forth her first-born son and wrapped him in swaddling clothes, etc.

St. Luke, chapter II, verses 4, 6 and 7.

9

Furthermore, both of the holy children were named by means of supernatural knowledge, as is shown in the following paragraph :

NAMING OF BUDDHA.

Five days after the birth of Buddha an important cerempny occurred. The Brahmins of the city met together, and the young boy received a name. This name was Siddhartha, (He who succeeds in all things). And it was chosen by means of supernatural knowledge.

Tumour, page 802.

NAMING OF JESUS.

And when eight days were accomplished for the circumcis¬ ing of the child, his name was, called Jesus, which was so« named of the angel before he- was conceived in the womb.

St. Luke, chapter II, verse si.

The events occurring during the infancy of Jesus, and relat¬ ing to him, nearly all agree with similar events occurring during the infancy of Buddha. One of the most striking of these is the story of Simeon’s visit, which is almost identical with the

story of Asita, as told below:

VISIT OF ASITA.

Asita is an ascetic, who has acquired the eight magical fac¬ ulties, one of which is the facul¬ ty of visiting the heavens. Happening to soar up into those pure regions one day, he is told by the host of devotes, or heavenly spirits, that a mighty Buddha is born in the world, who will establish the supremacy of the Buddhist Dharma.

Looking abroad with his di¬ vine eye, and considering the Kingdom of India, he saw in

And, behold, there was a man in Jerusalem, whose name was Simeon and the same man was just and devout, waiting for the consolation of Israel : and the Holy Ghost was upon him.

And it was revealed unto him by the Holy Ghost, that he should not see death, before he had seen the Lord’s Christ.

And he came by the spirit into the temple: and when the parents brought in the child Jesus, to do for him after the custom of the law,

Taking advantage of his pow¬ er, the old Brahmin rose aloft in the sky, and proceeded to the great city of Kapilavastu. Upon reaching the palace of the King, he said,

The similarities of these two stories are positively startling.

Both the Brahmin and the Jew Simeon were ascetics.

Both are represented as being inspired and influenced by supernatural powers.

Neither could die until he had seen the redeemer of mankind, and both of them prophesied the future of the holy child.

Let the following paragraphs decide whether the similarity lessens during the period of youth.

BOYHOOD OF BUDDHA.

Buddha’s teacher was named Yisvamitra. But the youthful Buddha soon showed that his lore was far greater than that of his teacher. When his teacher proposed to teach him the alphabet, the young prince in sounding 4 ‘ a ” pronounced it as in the sound of the word anitya ; in sounding “i” he pro¬ nounced it as in the word indri- ya, and so on through the whole Sanskrit alphabet.

Romantic History of Buddha, page 70.

At his writing lesson he dis¬ played the same miraculous proficiency, and no possible sum that his teachers or young com¬ panions could set him in arith¬ metic could baffle him. In poetry, grammar, in music, in singing, he also proved without a rival.

In joining his hands in prayer, in the knowledge of the Rig-Veda, and the holy books, in rites, in magic, and in

When taken to his school¬ master, Zacchaeus, the Lord Jesus explained to him the meaning of the letters, Aleph and Beth, also which were the straight figures of the letters, which were the oblique, and what letters had double figures.

The Lord Jesus further said to the masters, “Take notice how I say to thee. ” Then he ' began clearly and distinctly to say Aleph, Beth, Gimel, Daleth, and so on to the end of the al¬ phabet, etc., etc.

There was also among them a philosopher, well skilled in physics and natural philosophy, who asked the Lord Jesus whether He had studied phy^ sics. He replied and explained to him physics and metaphy¬ sics, also those things which were above and belong to the power of nature, etc., etc.

CHAPTER II.

While the creeds taught both by Buddha and Christ are practically the same, there is yet a slight difference in their man¬ ner of expression, which can undoubtedly he accounted for by the long lapse of time intervening between the lives of the two teachers. Before examining the teachings of each, however, we may notice in passing that Buddha, as well as Jesus, had dis¬ ciples whose mission it was to propagate their doctrines far and near.

DISCIPLES OF BUDDHA.

Buddha had twelve ‘‘Great Disciples,’’ and sixty minor disciples. “Only in my re¬ ligion,” said Buddha, sol¬ emnly, a little before he died, “can be found the twelve great disciples who practise the highest virtues and excite the world to free itself from its torments.”

Bigandet, page 301.

DISCIPLES OF JESUS.

And when he had called unto him his twelve disciples, he gave them power against un¬ clean spirits, etc., etc.

These twelve Jesus sent forth to preach, “The kingdom of heaven is at hand,” etc., etc.

St. Matthew, chapter X.

Let us now place side by side some of the principal teachings of Buddha and of Jesus. The similarities are so striking as to make the precepts taught seem almost identical. It should be ob¬ served also that each preached from a mountain.

TEACHINGS OF BUDDHA.

Buddha delivered a sermon on a mountain called the Elephant’s Head, located near Buddha-Gaya, which contains part of his teachings in a condensed form.

Bigandet, page 141.

CHAPTER III.

Through the desire to he brief, but a limited number of paral¬ lel examples have been presented to show the marvelous resemblance of Christianity to Buddhism. Yet in this brief space the stories of the birth of Jesus, of his life, of his death, of the miracles he performed, of the precepts he taught, have been given, and it has been shown how they correspond with analogous stories in the life of Buddha. It has also been shown how some of the principal Christian doctrines, notably those of the Trinity and of an Immaculate Conception, correspond in a remarkable manner with similar doctrines of Buddhism. In the same way the counterpart of nearly every one of the doctrines of orthodox Christianity can also be found in the holy books of Buddhism. Not only in the law, but in the ceremonies and out¬ ward form as well, does the comparison hold good. “Much of the dress of the Buddhist priest,” says Balfour’s Indian Encyclo¬ paedia, “and of the ritual, has a similarity to those of Christians of the Romish and Greek forms.”

Father Grueber, on visiting Sha-Sa, the capital of Thibet, in 1661, was much shocked to find that the devil had struck at Christianity in its most vital part. He had invented a mock potentate, to whom honors were paid that are due to the vicar of Christ alone. The faithful were required to fall flat before the Grand Llama of Thibet, to knock their heads upon the ground, and to crawl forward and kiss his feet. Like the Pope in Christi¬ anity, the Llama was the acknowledged head of the Buddhist Church all over the world. (See Lillie, Buddhism in Christendom.)

Indulgences and dispensations, much after the usage of the Catholic Church, were sold by the Buddhist monks. But more important for our consideration are the (Ecumenical

27

Councils introduced to suppress heresy. Where did they come from? Such an idea is foreign to the genius alike of the then dominant Roman and Jewish religions. In the records of Bud¬ dhism five principal (Ecumenical Councils are noticed.

The question that now confronts us is, By what manner or means was the Eastern philosophy carried to Palestine ? That question is answered by the indisputable evidence of histor}’. Buddha was not satisfied with teaching his new doctrine to the Hindus only, but gathering about him his disciples in the first year of his ministry, he sent them forth on the work of propa- gandism in the following words : “Depart each man in a different direction, no two on the same road. Let each man preach Dharma to all men without exception.”

And how thoroughly his commands were carried out is shown by the following extracts from Lillie’s book, Buddhism in Christendom :

“Within two hundred and fifty years of Buddha’s death (which “occurred five hundred years before the birth of Christ), King “ Asoka, the most powerful monarch in India, adopted Buddhism as “ the official religion of his land, and carved his creed on the rocks “ from the east coast of Hindustan to Ganyam on the west coast; “ and these evidences are still to be seen, besides the temples carved “in fine India woodwork, or built of solid masonry. Other in- ‘‘ scriptions which are carved indelibly in the rocks, contain the “fact that the Buddhist King Asoka was closely associated with “ the Greeks, and that he sent missionaries to Egypt. In the “ Mahawanso, or old history of Ceylon, it is announced that on the “occasion of the building of the Buddhist tope (temple) of “ Ruanwelli, enormous numbers of Buddhist monks came from 4 ‘ all parts, including thirty thousand from the vicinity of Alasadda, ‘the capital of the Youa (Greek) country. The word “Alasadda is agreed by all Orientalists to be Alexandria.”

Another proof that Buddhism was spreading- to Egypt and Palestine, is the fact that about this time there arose in Alexandria a teaching- called “ Gnosticism.” This word is the exact equiva¬ lent of Buddhism (Sans Bodhi), and it simply means interior or spiritual knowledg-e. That the early Christian Church was quite aware whence Gnosticism came is shown by the form of adjudication prescribed for those who renounced it. It expressly mentions Bodda and Sakya. Attempts have been made to put forward the date of the introduction of Gnosticism to the second century A. D., but Principal Tulloch, in an article in the new Encyclopaedia Britannica, shows how useless these attempts have been. He says that in the time of Christ, Egypt and Syria were so saturated with it that it was in the air. Tulloch, like Herder, Mosheim, Hammond, Bruckerand Muller, “discovers Gnosticism and the Eastern philosophy on almost every page of the New Testament. ”

It is well known that in Palestine, at the time of Jesus, there existed a certain sect of Jews, who were called Essenes. They were a small religious fraternity, whose name and origin, as well as character and history, are alike involved in obscurity. They obeyed the Mosaic law in a measure, but did not frater¬ nize or have anything in common with the Pharisees and Sadducees, who composed the other two sects of Judaism. The Essenes practised Confession and Baptism, two doctrines so entirely foreign to the teachings of Judaism, that the question arises, Who taught them? It could not have been Jesus, for he, being a direct descendant of King David, preached in the temple and belonged to the Pharisaic party, a sect that neither practiced nor believed in Baptism or Confession. (See Origin of Chris¬ tianity, by I. M. Wise).

The real leader of the Essenes was John the Baptist, a young

29

man full of enthusiasm and passion, who lived as an ascetic in the desert of Judea. Ernest Renan in his Life of Jesus, Page 118, speaks of him as follows: “From his infancy John was ‘‘ nazir, that is to say devoted by vow to certain abstinences. “The desert by which he was, as it were, environed, soon at¬ tracted him. He led in it the life of an Indian yogui, clad in “ skins or in stuff of camel’s hair and having no food but locusts “and wild honey. A certain number of disciples were gathered “about him, sharing his life and meditating upon his severe “words.”

John, the gospel tells us, preached both baptism and confes¬ sion (Matthew, Chapter II), and as these rites are considered fundamental principles of Buddhism, is it not fair to suppose that the Buddhist missionaries were just as successful in propagating their missions in Judea as they were in other lands, and that John was one of their converts?

Renan, Chapter VI. page 120, refers to this as follows : “We may believe in any event, that many of the external prac¬ tices of John, of the Essenes, and of the Jewish spiritual “preceptors of the time, came from a recent influence of the “upper East. The fundamental rite which characterized the “sect of John, and which gave him his name, has always had its “centre in Lower Chaldea and there constitutes a religion which “has been perpetuated to our day. That rite was baptism or “total immersion.”

When Jesus presented himself to John as a candidate for baptism, (“Then cometh Jesus from Galilee to Jordan unto John to be baptized of him,” Matthew, Chap. II.), he had resolved to sever entirely his connections with his own sect, the Pharisees, and to join without reserve the growing party of the Essenes. It was only after his initiation by baptism and John’s removal

30

from the leadership of the Essenes by arrest, that Jesus ascended the mount and preached the new doctrine as interpreted by John.

Renan, Chapter VI., page 126, says: “When he [Jesus] “began to preach after the arrest of John, the first words which “are put into his mouth are only a repetition of one of the “familiar phrases of the Baptist. Many other expressions of “ John are repeated literally in his discourses.”

Three vital points bearing directly on this question and con¬ firmed by the gospels must not be lost sight of:

I. That Jesus by birth and education belonged to a sect of the Jews that never countenanced baptism or confession.

II. That John the Baptist had an organization with disciples and many followers, who practiced baptism and confession long- before Jesus came to join it.

III. That Jesus did not begin preaching his new doctrine until after he had joined the Essenes party, and that his new doctrine, as has been shown by the parallel columns, is a modified version of Buddhism, adapted by Jesus to suit the times and circumstances of the people to whom he preached.

This fact has been recognized and tacitly acknowledged by many gentiles. Already a hundred years ago, Sir William Jones, a Christian scholar, boldly asserted that it is useless to attempt the conversion of the Hindus to Christianity, because the Indian religion contains nearly all that the Christian missionaries could oiler them. He said, “As to the general extension of our pure “faith in Hindustan there are at present many obstacles to it. “The Hindus would readily admit the truth of the Gospel, “ but they contend that it is perfectly consistent with their Sostras. “We may assure ourselves that neither Mussulmen nor Hindus “ will ever be converted by any mission from the Church of Rome, “ or from any other Church.”

Another thing is certain, and that is, that, inasmuch as Buddhism many years antedates Christianity, Buddha could not possibly have derived his teachings from the Gospels. Therefore, how can we escape from the conclusion that the story of the life of Jesus, as well as most of the doctrines and forms of orthodox Christianity, were taken from Buddhism ?
